entry.title: Re: Files need to transfer from SOFFPHF table to open tex...
entry.content: If the content server is temporarily unavailable, SAP may still allow attachments to be created, and those documents are then stored in the database, typically again in SOFFCONT1 or related SAPoffice tables. Once the content server is available again, these documents can be relocated using RSIRPIRL. There is no automatic fallback synchronization, so periodic relocation is required in such scenarios.

entry.title: Re: Store document from UI5 into SAP Archivelink
entry.content: From a practical point of view, you shouldnâ€™t store the xstring directly in your own table. The usual approach is to stream the file from UI5 to the backend (for example via OData create_stream) and then use standard ArchiveLink APIs to persist it. In ABAP you can use function modules like ARCHIV_CREATE_TABLE / ARCHIVOBJECT_CREATE_TABLE or SCMS_AO_TABLE_CREATE, as long as your content repository is already configured in OAC0/OACT. Another common option is to first save the file as a GOS/SAPoffice attachment and then relocate it to the external ArchiveLink repository using RSGOS_RELOCATE_ATTA. This keeps the database small and relies on standard SAP mechanisms.

entry.title: Re: Archive SOFFCONT1 Table using SARA
entry.content:
In S/4 migrations and also in ECC, SOFFCONT1 cannot be archived via SARA. There is no SAP archiving object for this table, so standard data archiving is simply not supported. Be careful here â€“ this is often missed and people assume SARA can handle it like application tables.

Post go-live we usually see this table grow because it stores raw attachment content. Without moving data to a content server or deleting orphaned entries, there is no way to reduce the DB footprint without risk. Any custom archiving via ADK would mean touching binary content, which carries data loss and audit break risk, especially for finance or legal attachments.

In high-volume sy

entry.title: Re: Facing Issue in GOS Attachment for MM03
entry.content: This usually happens because the attachment is created but not correctly linked to the material object, so MM03 doesnâ€™t show it. For GOS on materials, the object type must be BUS1001006 and the material number has to be in 18â€‘char internal format. Also make sure the folder, file extension, and header data are filled correctly before calling the link (ATTA). An easier and safer option is to use the standard class CL_GOS_DOCUMENT_SERVICE â†’ create_attachment, which handles the upload and linking automatically. Once the link exists in SRGBTBREL, the attachment will show up in MM03.

entry.title: Re: GOS attachment BADI implement GOS_SRV_SELECT
entry.content: This BAdI can only have one active implementation. In S/4HANA there is already a standard implementation (for example FIN_GOS_HTMLGUI) active, so when you try to activate your own one it gets deactivated with the message that it wonâ€™t be called. You usually canâ€™t switch off the standard implementation, so the practical option is to enhance the standard class (implicit enhancement) and add your logic there instead of creating a separate BAdI implementation.

entry.title: Re: Preventing Negative Balances in Cost Centers in SAP P...
entry.content: Yes, in SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud, you can use Budget Availability Control and Situation Handling to trigger warnings or alerts when a cost center approaches or exceeds its budget. While the system doesnâ€™t automatically block postings that drive balances negative, you can configure thresholds, notifications, and responsibility assignments to prevent surprises.  Check this blog  How Developer Extensibility lets you create your own Situation Handling Use Case from which, you can take the inputs under the heading "Cost center budget threshold exceeded"

entry.title: BI 2025 Requires license key generation
entry.content:
We saw some article 

DIGITS - How to generate license keys for SAP BusinessObjects Business Intelligence Platform (all versions) - SAP for Me - SAP for Me 

in that, when we click below link it does not work, it says page does not exist

 

  • It does not affect the existing license key, correct?
  • Who can submit the request for new license key, is it the person with super admin privileges?
  • Will it have the same number of concurrent licenses? and in how many environments can it be used?


--- Support Assistant ---
Q: What type of install action are you performing?
A: Updating & Patching

 


------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Learn more about the SAP Support user and program here.

entry.title: Re: BI 2025 Requires license key generation
entry.content:
Regarding to your questions, kindly check the answer as following:

  • https://me.sap.com/licensekey/wizard

    ----> this link is the old version license key app's link, the new one is https://me.sap.com/licensekeys/installations/selectionscreen

    The road to find the license key app: Services & Support -> Overview -> Request license key -> license keys
  • It does not affect the existing license key, correct?
    ---->Yes, it will not affect the existing license keys.

  • Who can submit the request for new license key, is it the person with super admin privileges?
    ----> S-user who has "request license key" authorizations could be able to submit the request, not only the super admin.

  • Will it have the same number of concurrent licenses? and in how many environments can it be used?
    ---->Yes, it will the same number of concurrent licenses and how may environments you have.

entry.title: How to digitally sign (using PKCS7 algo) MT101 DMEE payment file in S4 using ABAP
entry.content:
Hello experts,

My requirement is to digitally sign a DMEE file (MT101) using PKCS#7 algo and then encode the signed binary content in Base64 format and send the data to CPI. How can I do it in S4 before sending to CPI using ABAP. Thanks in advance!

Regards,

Sugato

entry.title: How inpeek Leveraged the SAP HANA Knowledge Graph Engine to Power a Chatbot for Structured Data
entry.content:
At inpeek , we are always looking for innovative ways to make our solutions smarter and more efficient. Our SaaS product Summarix supports us in managing CVs, project references, skills, customers, and more, enabling the seamless creation of call-for-tender documents. To make the work of our employees and sales team easier, we set out to simplify how users interact with Summarixâ€™s structured data. Out of this ambition, Summy, our AI-powered chatbot, was born. 

We realized this project in close collaboration with SAP through the Early Adopter Care (EAC) Program for the SAP HANA Knowledge Graph Engine, a powerful extension of the SAP HANA database. In the following sections, we will share details of the Summy project, the challenges we encountered, and the technical decisions that shaped the solution. 

The Challenge 

Summarix already provided a user-friendly UI with filtering and search capabilities built on SAP Fiori, SAP Cloud Application Programming Model (CAP) and deployed on SAP Business Technology Platform (BTP) . While this approach worked well for simple questions, it did have several limitations:  

  • Filters could only cover what the product owners or developers had envisioned. 
  • Complex questions across multiple entities quickly exceeded the UIâ€™s filter options. 
  • Aggregational queries (e.g., identifying the most experienced consultant in a skill or calculating the average years of experience over all consultants) were impossible with standard filters. 

In order to overcome these challenges and accelerate the search process, we envisioned a chatbot that would be capable of: 

  • Focus on information retrieval from structured data. 
  • Provide precise, single-turn answers to questions. 
  • Leverage new SAP technologies, particularly the SAP HANA Knowledge Graph Engine. 

This was also an opportunity for us to gain early hands-on experience with the Knowledge Graph Engine and to explore its potential.  

The Solution 

We implemented an innovative architecture built entirely on the SAP BTP. The system combines a knowledge graph and an agentic workflows to deliver precise answers to questions regarding the data stored in Summarix. 

â€ƒ

Key components of the solution: 

  • SAP HANA Knowledge Graph Engine: Stores data as a knowledge graph, facilitating SPARQL-based queries. 
  • SAP CAP backend: Manages orchestration, workflow logic, and query processing. While Python is a popular choice for many AI projects , we deliberately chose to integrate AI into our CAP (Node.js) backend using the SAP AI SDK. Utilising LangGraph.js and LangChain.js, we have modeled the agentic workflow directly in JavaScript. 
  • SAP Generative AI Hu: Provides access to LLM inference. We leverage its orchestration features and prompt templates, while retaining the flexibility to switch between models from OpenAI, Amazon, Google... 
  • Angular UI: A lightweight chat interface that runs as a shell plugin within the SAP Work Zone. 
  • Langfuse: Ensures observability and evaluation. This open-source tool enables us to trace executions, measure performance, and curate evaluation datasets. 

Key Features 

Our chatbot relies on an agentic AI workflow. While it is not a fully autonomous agent, the workflow defines a repeatable sequence of steps with conditional branches. This approach ensures consistency, reduces risks, and simplifies debugging, while still supporting dynamic, question-specific workflows and granting the agent some autonomy. 

Knowledge Graph Generation 

The project started with building the knowledge graph, which is based on the structured data from the SAP HANA Database of Summarix. This includes the following steps: 

  1. Export data from SQL into CSV. 
  1. Create graph nodes for entities (e.g., employees, projects, skills) with attributes while omitting irrelevant columns. 
  1. Model n-n relationships through connection nodes. 
  1. Export everything into Turtle (.ttl) files. 
  1. Ingest these files into the SAP HANA Knowledge Graph Engine. 

Ensuring data quality is paramount, as errors in this area can propagate through to the chatbot and significantly impact downstream task performance. As part of the ongoing development and implementation of improvements, the knowledge graph creation process has been repeatedly revised and enhanced . 

Entity Extraction and Matching 

Users naturally phrase questions in different ways (e.g., SAP BTP vs. SAP Business Technology Platform). Since each skill has a canonical name in Summarix, robust entity matching is required. 

Our approach, involved the following steps: 

  • Extract potential entities (skills, employees, projects and customers) from the question via an LLM using few-shot learning. 
  • Normalize entity names (singular form, multiple known variations). 
  • Search with regex-based case-insensitive filters for the existing entities. 

After matching the entities, we store them in the agent state for subsequent steps. 

SPARQL Query Generation 

After identifying the entities , the next step is to generate a SPARQL query. To guide the LLM, we did a lot of context engineering and provide: 

  • Context such as identity, instructions, and current date/time. 
  • The full ontology of the knowledge graph, including attributes and relationships. 
  • Detailed descriptions of all attributes, entities and relations. 
  • Examples of valid SPARQL queries. 

For this step, we (currently) rely on GPT-4.1 for its stronger reasoning capabilities, while lighter calls use GPT-4o-mini. 

We chose to use a knowledge graph approach, although it would also be possible to directly generate SQL and execute queries against the relational SAP HANA Cloud database. In our experiments, answers based on SQL queries showed slightly lower performance compared to those derived from the knowledge graph approach. 

Evaluation and Observability 

From day one,, we prioritized evaluation at inpeek to avoid a â€œblack-boxâ€ development process and to establish clear KPIs and track their development over time. The key steps of our evaluation include: 

  • Curated a baseline dataset (~30 items) with questions and ground truth answers. 
  • Built an evaluation API endpoint to automatically rerun the dataset after each iteration. 
  • Use LLM-as-a-judge scoring (0â€“1) to assess the correctness of an answer compared to the ground truth answer. 
  • Introduced user feedback loops: flagged chatbot answers are added to new datasets, enabling continuous improvement based on previous incorrect answers. 
  • Track additional metrics, such as latency, costs and self-correction steps. 

Key Technical Considerations 

  • Multi-tenancy: Since Summarix is a SaaS product, we implemented our own multi-tenant logic to support different environments. So far , the SAP HANA Knowledge Graph does not offer multi-tenancy capabilites.  
  • Automated KG ingestion: A tenant-aware Python job daily updates the knowledge graph as data evolves in Summarix. 
  • CAP instead of Python: By keeping everything in CAP (Node.js), we simplified integration with authentication, lifecycle management, and SAP tooling. 
  • Context engineering: Providing a complete ontology with extended descriptions is crucial for reliable SPARQL generation. 
  • Evaluation-first approach: Systematic evaluation ensured objective improvements and prevented regressions.

Conclusion 

With Summy, we explored how the SAP HANA Knowledge Graph Engine can serve as a foundation for Retrieval-Augmented Generation (RAG) on structured data. By combining knowledge graphs, SPARQL, LLMs and agentic workflows, we created a chatbot that can provide precise answers to complex business questions. This means consultants and sales reps can now answer tender-related questions in seconds instead of manually filtering data! 

This project demonstrated that success hinges on more than just the agent workflow, it also depends on data quality, entity mapping and evaluation pipelines. We had an excellent experience with the SAP HANA Knowledge Graph Engine and look forward to building on this foundation for future use cases. 

There is also a Medium blog post that delves deeper into the AI Engineering aspect, as well as a SAP Success Story highlighting the use of the knowledge graph for the chatbot and our SaaS solution, Summarix

If youâ€™d like to learn more about this project or discuss AI in the SAP ecosystem, feel free to conntact us on LinkedIn: 

Fabian HÃ¼ni (AI Engineer)
Fabian KÃ¼ng (SAP Expert Consultant)

entry.title: SAP Joule Extensibility - With Joule Studio Skill Builder
entry.content:
During TechEd, AI was a central theme across nearly all sessions â€” it was rare to find one where the term â€œAIâ€ wasnâ€™t mentioned. Many of these sessions focused on Joule agents, skills, and the Agent Builder, which is expected to be released by the end of December 2025.

That said, Joule Studio is already available today as part of Build Process Automation. In addition to the upcoming Agent Builder, it is currently possible to extend Jouleâ€™s capabilities using Custom Joule Skills through the Joule Skill Builder.

To put it simply, we are still running S/4HANA 2022 FPS02, and features such as Sales Order Fulfillment and Monitoring (SAP Note 3459573) via Joule are only available in later releases. As a result, asking Joule transactional questions related to Sales Orders does not yield any response.

Hereâ€™s where the Joule Skill Builder in Joule Studio comes into play.

We could create a custom skill and leverage existing BAPIs in the S/4HANA system. (First, a destination must be configured in the BPA BTP subaccount to establish the connection with the S/4 system.)

Once the S/4 system is accessible from BPA via this destination, the next step is to define actionsâ€”specifying which fields, tasks, and data should be retrieved from S/4 using the relevant BAPIs (in this case, those related to Sales Orders).

The only mandatory input field required is the Sales Document Number; all other fields have been excluded from the selection.

The following are the only output fields (or outputs) of interest for this Joule Skill.

Once the Action is defined, weâ€™re ready to build our first basic Joule Skill. Iâ€™ll include a few numbered screenshots to illustrate the process and explain the overall flow.

 

Once the skill is deployed in your BPA environment, you can grant and share access to other users using the Share option. To test the skill, simply launch the standalone Joule using the Launch button.

The skill can also be deployed and made available to the central/shared Joule instance that is enabled across the SAP landscape, encompassing both private and public cloud systems and services (via Joule Formation).

Now we can retry the same Sales Order queries to check if Joule can provide meaningful responses. This time, I invoked Joule directly from our S/4HANA system, rather than launching it as a standalone instance from BPA.

Although this functionality is not natively supported in the S/4HANA version we are currently running, we successfully extended Jouleâ€™s capabilities by creating custom skills to address a simple, practical use case.

Disclaimer: An additional skill was also developed to demonstrate the Card with Buttons feature; however, it is not covered here ğŸ™‚

Helpful Links

How to Get Started with Joule Studio

Set Up Joule Studio

Mission in Discovery Center

entry.title: TM Module- Apart from Freight order, process Freight charges that need to be paid to the PO Supplier
entry.content:
Dear Experts,

When running Transportation Management Module, for handling Import Freight charges, there are specific freight charges that need to be paid to the PO supplier.

In our case, the PO supplier of goods is different to the Freight Carrier.  Through TM process we are able to capture freight costs (payable to freight Carrier) and do the Freight cost distribution over material inventory on accruals posting. But, additionally there are a few freight costs payable to the PO supplier of Goods ONLY, these costs we need to record for only few items of the PO (in partials quantities) will be liable to these costs. The PO contains more than 100 line items and each freight unit may contain only 10 or less number of items with partial quantities.

Thus, we can not handle these charges in the below methods:

  1. Add these freight charges in the header level PO charges. Since these are intended to be split over only the Freight unit items.
  2. Add these charges in Item level - the freight units have 10 - 15 items, ideally. The Buyer can not go into individual PO line charges and distribute the freight charges before GRN.
  3. Add these charges as unplanned delivery costs in the MIRO booking, since the Invoice booking may be delayed from GRN, the stock may be consumed by then.

We need your advice on how to capture these freight charges in the our P2P process with TM.

Thanks,

Zahir

entry.title: SAP Joule Document Grounding (Business AI)
entry.content:
tâ€™s finally time to explore Document Grounding and train Joule to answer questions using your companyâ€™s specific policy and knowledge documents. But before diving into Joule, itâ€™s important to first understand Retrieval Augmented Generation.

 

  • Retrieval: When you ask a question, the system first searches a database, documents, or knowledge source (like a companyâ€™s files, research papers) for the relevant information.
  • Augmentation: Those retrieved documents are passed into the language model as extra context.
  • Generation: The model then uses both its own knowledge and the retrieved information to produce an answer that is more accurate and grounded in facts.

 

This helps reduce hallucinations (when an AI makes things up) and allows the model to answer questions about data it wasnâ€™t originally trained on.

In line with the general SAP documentation approach, we used SharePoint as the content ingestion platform. This means that once you create and execute a data pipeline, documents from your selected SharePoint sites and folders are successfully ingested into the pipeline. After ingestion, Joule can leverage this information to augment its responses.

The setup is technically intensive. For those interested in testing this outâ€”and to avoid overloading this post with technical jargonâ€”the SAP TechEd session on Setting up Joule to answer questions in your own policy documents is the best starting point.

We used Bruno as the tool to setup a data pipeline between SharePoint and BTP subaccount running Joule.

 

Below are a couple of examples where we set up a data pipeline to make Joule aware of Kardex (Kardex is an Automatic Storage Retrieval System). We also ingested specific HR policy documents.

As a result, when queried, Joule is contextually aware of this information and provides grounded responses specific to this knowledge base.

 

Be prepared for some issues and challenges during the deployment along the way and reference this great post " Joule â€“ Getting Started with Document Grounding"to solve some of them

Pre-Requisites for using Joule Document Grounding:

  • Youâ€™ve purchased the AI Unit SKU (8019164) and AI units.
  • Youâ€™ve added the entitlements for document grounding to the subaccount where youâ€™ve subscribed to Joule.
  • Youâ€™ve enabled Identity Authentication with Cloud Identity Services

entry.title: New Machine Learning, NLP and AI features in SAP HANA Cloud 2025 Q4
entry.content:
With the SAP HANA Cloud 2025 Q4 release, several new embedded Machine Learning / AI functions  have been released with the with the Predictive Analysis Library (PAL), the Automated Predictive Library (APL) and the NLP Services in SAP HANA Cloud.

Key new capabilities to be highlighted include

  • A new unified time series procedure, serving developers to utilize the same interface across different times series algorithms
  • text embedding model enhancements, supporting output vector dimensionality reduction, while maintaining retrieval accuracy
  • a new cross encoder model with the NLP services, for accurately re-ranking search results
  • text column input, text embedding operators with AutoML classification and regression models
  • text tokenization enhancements supporting regular expression token filtering and a new text log parsing function for detecting and determining new log pattern
  • the HANA ML experiment monitor UI now supports visual model monitoring and drift analysis

An enhancement summary is available in the Whatâ€™s new document for SAP HANA Cloud database 2025.40 (QRC 4/2025).

 

Time series enhancements

Introducing Unified Time Series interfaces

Unified time series is a newly introduced interface for a simplified use of multiple time series algorithms (ARIMA, Exponential Smoothing, Bayesian Structural Time Series (BSTS) and Additive Model Analysis (aka prophet)).

  • it allows for application developers to flexibly consume different time series analysis algorithms using the same procedure interface and a harmonized the handling of time series data patterns, avoiding algorithm-specific data preparation.
  • It also supports massive, data-parallel time series modeling for maximum parallelism and performance when modeling thousands of time series in parallel

 

A more detailed introduction to the new function is given in the following blog post https://community.sap.com/t5/technology-blog-posts-by-sap/simplifying-time-series-analytics-with-unified-time-series-interface/ba-p/14292218

 

AutoML time series now support Prediction Intervals

AutoML time series predict function, in addition to all regular time series functions, now supports prediction intervals for probabilistic forecasting

  • the uncertainty associated with a forecast is quantified by providing a range (lower/upper bounds) into which a future observation likely falls with a specific confidence level.
  • For example a 95% prediction interval contains the true value 95% of the time

 

Text embedding model enhancements (NLP services)

Output vector dimension reduction

The Text Embedding models in SAP HANA Cloud have been enhanced with an attached a linear layerâ€‹â€‹, derived from PCA trainings, to allow for the output vector dimensionality reduction

  • The arget dimension cardinality can be flexibly set to 128, 256 384, 512, 768 dimensions using â€‹â€‹PCA_DIM_NUM parameter
  • A near-original retrieval task accuracy is sustained with 256 dimensions, at 1/3rd of the original vector size (768 dimensions)
  • While lower dimension values than 128 would lead to significant and critical-level accuracy loss for retrieval tasks, hence 256 dimensionsâ€‹â€‹ is recommended for efficiency & performance

Now text embeddings of significantly lower dimensionality can be utilized at a minimal information loss for retrieval tasks as well as machine learning.

Moreover smaller vector sizes unlock much faster machine learning processing times and may also serve vector retrieval queries

 

Text feature data support with AutoML models

Text column data and Text Embedding Operator in AutoML models

With the introduction of the a new text embedding operator for AutoML models, text columns can be directly used as input feature data and benefit from automatic, and optimized text vectorization utilizing SAP HANA Clouds text embedding models.

  • Text columns can be processed as feature, specified with the new parameter TEXT_VARIABLE
  • In addition, the new TextEmbedding operator supports the new target dimension reduction with the parameter PCA_DIM_NUM 
  • The enhancement are available with the SQL interface as well as hana-ml 2.27 in Python

With that, the semantic insights from text columns can get automatically unlocked when building AutoML classification / regression models.

 

Cross Encoder Model (NLP services)

Accurate re-ranking of search results

The family NLP services in SAP HANA Cloud has now been enriched with a new cross encoder model and respective PAL functions. The cross encoder model

  • Processes pairs/sets of text sentences (query, candidate results) together
  • Therefore allows for a more precise semantic similarity re-ranking of search results, based on the full contextual interaction analysis between the query and the input candidate set (e.g. a an initial result set retrieved from a vector engine similarity search)
  • Thus much higher accurate and relevant-ranked similarity search results can be achieved

 

Moreover the use of cross encoder models allows to combine multiple result sets retrieved from for example classic text search and vector engine similarity search queries into a hybrid search result, which can be passed into the cross encoder for its overall and combined re-ranking.

Custom AI, Retrieval Augmented Generation Applications (RAG) can now fully be served by Text Embedding Models, Vector Engine with Similarity Search and the Cross Encoder model, managing context privacy from the SAP HANA Cloud database.

 

Text tokenization enhancements and new automated log text analysis

Text tokenization support for regular expressions

The text pre-processing function Text Tokenize function for splitting input text into smaller units called tokens, has now been enhanced and supports regular expression for filtering token output patterns.

  • Custom filtering (removal/keeping) of text patterns can be applied
  • List of regular expressions, matching tokens will be kept / excluded
  • Typical filtering examples include extracting e-mail addresses, URLs, or other token patterns for domain-specific needs

 

Automatic pattern detection from log texts

A new analysis function for log text documents Text Log Parse has been added to the Predictive Analysis Library, which allows

  • For an automatic extraction of new log patterns and derive templates for new log patterns
  • High-performant processing of log texts for log classification and automated log analysis, the ability to detect and alert for new log patterns

 

 

ML experiment tracking and task scheduling enhancements

Experiment tracking enhancements

Tracking of experiments, now supports custom track entity tags

  • Standard track entities generated in PAL Training, Forecast, etc. can now be enriched with custom tags like business related information associated with related track entity
  • Tag is name-value pair for annotation or note, binding extra information to existing entities

 

A more detailed introduction is provided in the following blog post comprehensive-guide-to-mltrack-in-sap-hana-cloud-end-to-end-machine 

Moreover the Experiment Monitor in the Python Machine Learning client (hana-ml) supports for visually monitoring ML model performance degradation and drift.

 

One-off scheduling of PAL tasks

The PAL procedure scheduling interfaces has been enhance with a One-OFF schedule option, allowing for

  • ad-hoc, automatic one-off scheduled execution of PAL task procedures with dynamic setting of time-frequency information based on current UTC timestamp
  • it triggers a scheduled job to execute immediately, and the corresponding one-off schedule is removed right away and doesnâ€™t require to be manually maintained.

 

Python ML client (hana-ml) enhancements

The full list of new methods and enhancements with hana_ml 2.27  is summarized in the changelog for hana-ml 2.27 as part of the documentation.  You can find an examples notebook illustrating the highlighted feature enhancements here 25QRC04_2.27.ipynb.

The key enhancements in this release include the following: 

Time series data outlier detection with threshold support

The method for time series outlier detection in the Predictive Analysis Library has added support outlier threshold settings, in addition to the outlier voting capability using different outlier evaluation methods incl.  Z1 score, Z2 score, IIQR score, MAD score, IsolationForest and DBSCAN

  • If the absolute value of outlier score is beyond the threshold, the respective data point will be considered as an outlier.

Time series reports for massive, data-parallel model scenarios

Massive AutoML Time Series modeling scenarios often utilize random-search with hyperband as the fastest optimization, potentially with larger number of time series data segment groups to be processed and forecasted in parallel, each time series segment group again with a significant number of forecast models to be explored. 

Hence the display of forecasts which have been explored by AutoML within each time series segment group is collapsed by default and can be expanded for review.

 

 

Classification and regression function enhancements

Support Vector Machine (SVM) model training is computationally expensive, and computational costs are specifically sensitive to the number of training points, which makes SVM models often impractical for large datasets.

The SVM algorithm now supports Coreset Sampling

  • which allows to automatically sample small, representative subsets (the "coreset") from larger datasets,
  • enabling faster, more efficient training and processing while maintaining similar model accuracy as using the full data.

This enhancement significantly reduces SVM training time with minimal impact on accuracy.

 

The model report for classification tasks now supports a percentage display in confusion matrix for easier visual interpretation of classification results.

 

High-dimensional feature data reduction using UMAP

UMAP (Uniform Manifold Approximation and Projection) is a non-linear dimensionality reduction algorithm used to simplify complex, high-dimensional feature spaces, while preserving its essential structure. It is widely considered the modern gold standard for visualizing targeted dimension reduction of large-scale datasets, because it balances computational speed with the ability to maintain both local and global relationships.

  • It reduces thousands of variables (dimensions) into 2D or 3D scatter plots that humans can easily interpret.
  • Unlike comparable methods like t-SNE, UMAP is better at preserving global structure, meaning the relative positions between different clusters remain more meaningful.
  • It is significantly faster and more memory-efficient than t-SNE, capable of processing datasets with millions of points in a reasonable timeframe.
  • It can be used as a "transformer" preprocessing step in Machine Learning scenarios to reduce large feature spaces before applying clustering (e.g., k-means, HDBSCAN) or classification models, often improving their performance.

 

Calculating pairwise distances

Many algorithms, for example clustering algorithms utilize distance matrixes as a preprocessing step, often inbuild the functions. Often there is the wish to decouple though the distance matrix calculation from the follow-up task like the actual clustering. Moreover, if decoupled custom calculated matrixes can be fed into algorithms as input.

  • Most PAL clustering functions support to feed-in a pre-calculated similarity matrix

Now, a pairwise distance calculation function is provided

  • It supports distance metrics like Manhattan, Euclidien, Minkowski, Chebyshey as well as Levenshtein
  • The Levenshtein distance (or edit distance) is a distance metric specifically targeting distance between text-columns. It calculates the minimum number of single-character edits (insertions, deletions, or substitutions) needed to transform one word into another, acting as a measure of their similarity. A lower distance indicates a higher similarity.

Applicable use cases

  • It is useful in data cleaning, table column similarity analysis between columns of the same data type.
  • After calculating the column similarity across all data types, clustering like K-Means can be applied to group similar fields and propose mappings for fields within the same cluster

 

Again, an incredible set of enhancements in the SAP HANA Cloud database AI engine and NLP services!

Enjoy to try out all the enhancements and let us know what you think here!

entry.title: Hands-On Guide: SAP Build + Joule Skill for Purchase Order Listing, Approval, or Modification
entry.content:
Introduction

In this tutorial, we will build an AI powered Purchase Order listing, modification or approval app using SAP Build and Joule. This step by step guide covers everything from OData integration to creating a working Joule Skill.

 

Table of Contents

  • 1. Create an Environment
  • 2. Exposing the Destination
  • 3. Create a database table to store purchase orders
  • 4. Create a CDS from the ZTABLE for Odata
  • 5. Create OData service with T-code SEGW
  • 6. Activate the Odata service via /iwfnd/maint_service T-code
  • 7. Crete an Action in SAP Build
  • 8. Create A Joule Skill to Get Purchase Order
  • 9. Create A Joule Skill to Approve Purchase Order
  • 10. Launch The Joule and Test The Skills

 

 

In todayâ€™s SAP ecosystem, intelligent automation is an expectation, not a future goal. SAP Build allows developers to quickly create business applications without extensive coding and SAP Joule brings AI-driven intelligence to these experiences.

In this hands-on guide, Iâ€™ll walk you through the process of building a Joule skill that connects to an OData service, allowing users to list, approve, and update purchase orders directly through SAP Build. ( This guide uses ZTABLE to store purchase order data because the standard SAP tables in the test system I work on don't have enough or the right kind of data. However, you can use the standard tables instead of ZTABLE. )

This project shows how AI capabilities can seamlessly integrate into SAPâ€™s low-code environment, enabling automation and human decision-making in one interface. Whether you want to enhance your workflow with intelligent actions or explore real-world Joule integration scenarios, this guide will provide a practical starting point.

 

1. Create an Environment

 

We need to create an environment for testing joule skill.

Open the SAP Build Lobby, choose Control Tower->Environments and press the Create button.

 

 

Name your environment and add Description.

 

2. Exposing the Destination

 

Url of the destination on BTP is the url of our SAP system and the destination must have these properties: 

sap.applicationdevelopment.actions.enabled -> true

sap.processautomation.enabled -> true

sap.build.usage -> odata_gen

 

Also the destinationâ€™s user will be used for set an external break-point for debugging the ABAP code.

 

 

Open the SAP Build Lobby, choose Control Tower->Destinations and press the Add button.

 

Select the Destination and choose next.

 

Choose the environment in which you want to use the target. For this tutorial you can choose the Test Environment that you create.

 

3. Create a database table to store purchase orders

@EndUserText.label : 'Purchase Order Change With Sap Build'
@AbapCatalog.enhancementCategory : #NOT_CLASSIFIED
@AbapCatalog.tableCategory : #TRANSPARENT
@AbapCatalog.deliveryClass : #A
@AbapCatalog.dataMaintenance : #ALLOWED
define table zbg_build_test {
  key mandt                      : mandt not null;
  key purchaseorder              : ebeln not null;
  key purchaseorderitem          : ebelp not null;
  key reservationitem            : ebelp not null;
  material                       : matnr;
  materialcompisvariablesized    : boolean;
  materialcomponentisphantomitem : boolean;
  reservation                    : char10;
  @Semantics.quantity.unitOfMeasure : 'zbg_build_test.entryunit'
  requiredquantity               : menge_d;
  requirementdate                : dats;
  reservationisfinallyissued     : boolean;
  baseunit                       : meins;
  @Semantics.quantity.unitOfMeasure : 'zbg_build_test.entryunit'
  quantityinentryunit            : menge_d;
  entryunit                      : meins;
  plant                          : werks_d;
  latestrequirementdate          : dats;
  billofmaterialitemnumber       : ebelp;
  bomitemcategory                : char1;
  isbulkmaterialcomponent        : boolean;
  debitcreditcode                : shkzg;
  @Semantics.quantity.unitOfMeasure : 'zbg_build_test.entryunit'
  withdrawnquantity              : menge_d;
  approver                       : uname;
  appoved                        : flag;

}

 

Fill the table:

 

 

4. Create a CDS from the ZTABLE for Odata

 

@AbapCatalog.sqlViewName: 'ZSLV_BUILD_TST_V'
@AbapCatalog.compiler.compareFilter: true
@AbapCatalog.preserveKey: true
@AccessControl.authorizationCheck: #NOT_REQUIRED
@EndUserText.label: 'Purchasing Document Informations CDS'
@Metadata.ignorePropagatedAnnotations: true
@ObjectModel.deleteEnabled: true
@ObjectModel.createEnabled: true
@ObjectModel.updateEnabled: true
define view ZSLV_V_BUILD_TEST as select from zbg_build_test as z 
    
{   @EndUserText.label: 'Purchase Order'
    key purchaseorder,
    @EndUserText.label: 'Purchase Order Item'
    key purchaseorderitem,
    @EndUserText.label: 'Reservation Item'
    key reservationitem,
    @EndUserText.label: 'Material'
    material,
    @EndUserText.label: 'Material Size'
    materialcompisvariablesized,
    @EndUserText.label: 'Material Item'
    materialcomponentisphantomitem,
    @EndUserText.label: 'Reservation'
    reservation,
    @EndUserText.label: 'Quantity'
    requiredquantity,
    @EndUserText.label: 'Date'
    requirementdate,
    @EndUserText.label: 'Reservation Issue'
    reservationisfinallyissued,
    @EndUserText.label: 'Unit'
    baseunit,
    @EndUserText.label: 'Entry Unit'
    entryunit,
    @EndUserText.label: 'Quantity In Entry Unit'
    quantityinentryunit,
    @EndUserText.label: 'Plant'
    plant,
    @EndUserText.label: 'Latest Requirement Date'
    latestrequirementdate,
    @EndUserText.label: 'Bill Of Material Number'
    billofmaterialitemnumber,
    @EndUserText.label: 'BOM Item Category'
    bomitemcategory,
    @EndUserText.label: 'Is Bulk Material'
    isbulkmaterialcomponent,
    @EndUserText.label: 'Debit Credit Code'
    debitcreditcode,
    @EndUserText.label: 'With Drawn Quantity'
    withdrawnquantity,
    @EndUserText.label: 'Approver'
    approver,
    @EndUserText.label: 'Approved'
    appoved 
    
}

 

5. Create OData service with T-code SEGW

(Because of the version of the system I work on, this guide uses SEGW instead of RAP to create an OData service. However, you can easily create your own OData service with RAP.)

Press â€˜Create Projectâ€™ button, fill the fields and assign the package, request (For this tutorial it will be local object).

 

Complete the creation.

 

Extend the project, right click to â€˜Data Modelâ€™, select the Reference->Source

 

 

Fill the CDS name that you created. Choose â€˜Nextâ€™.

 

 

Choose â€˜Finishâ€™.

 

 

Activate and generate the Service:

 

 

Go to the class ZCL_ZSLV_BUILD_DPC_EXT. At the bottom of the method list redefine the update method ZSLV_V_BUILD_TES_UPDATE_ENTITY.

 

 

In the method, update the approved field with the below code and activate it.

 

METHOD zslv_v_build_tes_update_entity.
 
  DATA: lv_ebeln TYPE ebeln,
        lv_ebelp TYPE ebelp,
        lv_item  TYPE ebelp,
        ls_entity TYPE zcl_zslv_build_mpc=>ts_zslv_v_build_testtype,
        lr_entity TYPE REF TO data,
        ls_table TYPE zbg_build_test.
 
  LOOP AT it_key_tab INTO DATA(ls_key).
    CASE ls_key-name.
      WHEN 'purchaseorder'.
        lv_ebeln = ls_key-value.
      WHEN 'purchaseorderitem'.
        lv_ebelp = ls_key-value.
      WHEN 'reservationitem'.
        lv_item = ls_key-value.
    ENDCASE.
  ENDLOOP.
 
  io_data_provider->read_entry_data( IMPORTING es_data = ls_entity ).
  MOVE-CORRESPONDING ls_entity TO ls_table.
  er_entity = ls_entity.
  UPDATE zbg_build_test FROM ls_table.
  COMMIT WORK.
 
ENDMETHOD.

 

6. Activate the Odata service via /iwfnd/maint_service T-code

 

Choose â€˜Add Serviceâ€™

 

 

Select the â€˜System Aliasâ€™, fill the â€˜Technical Service Nameâ€™ and press â€˜Get Servicesâ€™. Select the service that you create and press â€˜Add Selected Servicesâ€™.

 

 

Assign the package and continue.

 

 

We have added the service, which should appear as follows. In the ICF Nodes section, there is a button labeled "SAP Gateway Client" that provides a testing environment for the service. Press that button.

 

 

Select the HTTP method as â€˜GETâ€™. Press â€˜EntitySetsâ€™ to choose entity set. Choose the one that you created.

 

 

Press â€˜Executeâ€™ button for testing and response should appear as follows.

 

 

7. Crete an Action in SAP Build

 

Open the SAP Build Lobby, choose Connectors->Actions and press the â€˜Createâ€™ button. Choose â€˜OData Destinationsâ€™ and select the Destination that we created.

 

 

Fill the Resource Path as follows and click â€˜Nextâ€™.

 

 

The available methods are listed in this window. Select â€˜Nextâ€™.

 

 

Fill the name and description for your action and create.

 

 

The action Purchase_Order_Action is created. Click the action and open it.

 

 

Select the methods in the OData Service.

 

 

The GET method's input has no required fields, only optional GET parameters.

 

 

Output parameters are the fields in the CDS that we created. 

 

 

Methods can be tested in the action interface. For the GET method we donâ€™t need to fill any input parameters. Click â€˜Testâ€™ button.

 

 

The data appears on the â€˜Test Previewâ€™ section.

 

 

The PATCH method requires purchaseorder, purchaseorderitem and reservationitem, all of which are key fields in our ZTABLE and CDS.

 

 

There are no standard output in PATCH method.

 

 

In the Test section, all required fields and fields that need to be changed must be filled out. In this scenario these fields are purchaseorder, purchaseorderitem, reservationitem and approved fields.

 

Also the link on the Test section can be used in the SAP Gateway Client to test the PATCH method.

 

 

 

PATCH method return â€œ204: NO CONTENTâ€ and empty Response. This means the update is successful and we will use this emptiness in our joule skill.

 

 

After checking and testing, save the methods using the â€˜Saveâ€™ button and select â€˜Releaseâ€™. After the release process, the action should appear as shown below. Then, press 'Publish'.

 

 

You can debug when testing methods via the SAP Gateway Client or the SAP Build Action. Set an external breakpoint for the user in your destination that we created at the beginning.

 

 

For the PATCH method, our key fields in the internal table IT_KEY_TAB. 

 

 

8. Create A Joule Skill to Get Purchase Order

 

Open the SAP Build Lobby, choose Create->Joule Skill and fill the name and description. Open the created skill.

 

 

Select the â€™Triggerâ€™ step. On the â€˜Generalâ€™ tab fill the name and description. Allow Joule to generate a response and skill to be started directly by user.

 

 

We don't need input, but outputs can vary according to our needs. In this tutorial, the parameters shown below have been added as outputs.

Choose â€˜Configureâ€™ and add parameters you want to show to the user. For this example, all parameters are string except the â€˜approvedâ€™ which is boolean.

 

 

 

Press â€˜+â€™ and choose â€˜Call Actionâ€™, â€˜Browse All Actionsâ€™.

 

 

Search for â€˜ZSLV_V_BUILD_TESTâ€™ or your Service Name. Add the â€˜Get entities from ZSLV_V_BUILD_TESTâ€™.

 

 

Select the â€˜Destination Variableâ€™ as Destination we created. 

 

 

We can skip the input tab because there are no input for GET method.

 

 

We can see the output parameters in this tab.

 

 

On the "End" step, we need to assign the input and output parameters for the skills. Since we don't have any inputs, let's assign the outputs added in the "Trigger" step as our action's outputs.

 

 

Save the Joule Skill.

 

 

And Release.

 

 

Now Deploy.

 

 

Choose the Environment we created and click â€˜Upgradeâ€™.

 

 

Match the destinations, and the skill will be ready to use by Joule after deployment.

 

 

9. Create A Joule Skill to Approve Purchase Order

 

On the â€˜Triggerâ€™ step, fill the name and description. Deactivate the â€˜Allow Joule to generate a responseâ€™ feature because in this skill we will create our own messages. The other feature should be active.

 

 

Configure the input parameters. Add purchaseorder, purchaseorderitem and reservationitem key fields as string. For approve skill we donâ€™t need any output field.

 

 

Choose â€˜+â€™ and â€˜Call Actionâ€™.

 

 

Browse All Actions.

 

 

Search update or the service name. Add the Update entity in ZSLV_V_BUILD_TEST.

 

 

On the â€˜Generalâ€™ tab, assign the Destination.

 

 

On the â€˜Inputsâ€™ tab, assign the purchaseorder, purchaseorderitem and reservationitem to the parameters created on the "Trigger" step.

 

 

We only need to fill the fields â€˜approvedâ€™ from the fields to be updated. We need to configure the â€˜approvedâ€™ field because action inputs can only be string. 

 

Choose â€˜approvedâ€™ field and â€˜Apply a formulaâ€™.

 

Type â€˜trueâ€™ and click â€˜Applyâ€™.

 

 

Choose â€˜+â€™ and â€˜Check Conditionâ€™.

 

 

Choose the â€˜Condition Editorâ€™.

 

 

Add the following conditions and Click â€˜Applyâ€™. If PATCH method is executed successfully, the result will be empty. 

 

 

If the condition is met, the left branch of the condition executes. In the opposite case, the â€˜Defaultâ€™ branch of the condition executes.

 

Choose the â€˜+â€™ on the left branch and â€˜Send Responseâ€™.

 

 

Open Message Editor.

 

 

Fill the parameters as shown below and save.

 

 

You can add parameters to the title and message with the â€˜<>â€™ button.

 

 

Do the same steps for the right branch of the condition. â€˜+â€™ -> â€™Send Responseâ€™ -> â€˜Open Message Editorâ€™

 

Fill the parameters as shown below and save.

 

 

Save, Release and Deploy just like the previous GET_PURCHASE_ORDER skill.

 

10. Launch The Joule and Test The Skills

 

Open the SAP Build Lobby, choose Control Tower->Environments->Joule

 

 

Launch the joule, ask for Purchase Orders and get the details.

 

 

Ask joule to approve the purchase orders and get the illustrated success message card we create.

entry.title: Re: Idoc set up by Basis
entry.content:
Your questions are very general and hence you'd better ask a GenAI engine.

Quick answers to your questions:

  1. What basis has to set up for IDoc integration?

    • The transaction code SPRO is the guide to setup anything in the system. Starting activity: SAP NetWeaver > Application Server > IDoc Interface / ALE (which corresponds to the transaction code SALE).

  2. is this only RFC connection between 2 systems?

    • The types of connections between systems are defined via IDoc Ports in the transaction code WE21 (RFC, file and Web service essentially)

  3. when Inbound IDoc send from other system, how system know that IDoc arrive and will process or not?

    • If it's RFC or Web service, the SAP inbound function module is called immediately. You may choose a file if the target system is not an ABAP-based system (file has no interest if it's an ABAP system), you may trigger a script in the remote system (all logic is custom or managed by third-party software).

entry.title: Did you know SAP BTP Destination Fragments and how to consume to integrate ?
entry.content:
In the era of hyper-automation and low-code/no-code platforms, seamless connectivity between services is critical. SAP BTPâ€™s Destination Fragments provide a standardized, reusable approach to managing API endpoints, security configurations, and network policies.

This blog explores how developers can consume Destination Fragments in SAP Build Apps, Process Automation, and other development contexts to accelerate integration, enhance security, and streamline governance.

Reference : SAP Help Documentation - Destinations with Fragments

1. What Are Destination Fragments?

Destination Fragments are reusable configuration components in SAP BTP that define:

  • Target endpoints (e.g., SAP S/4HANA, SAP SuccessFactors, or external APIs).
  • Authentication methods (OAuth, Basic Auth, Client Certificates).
  • Network policies (e.g., CORS, whitelisting).
  • Custom headers or query parameters.

Fragments are consumed by Destinations, which act as unified gateways for applications to access backend systems securely.

2. Why Consume Destination Fragments?

  • Reusability: Define once, use across multiple applications.
  • Security Centralization: Enforce consistent authentication and encryption.
  • Governance: Ensure compliance with enterprise policies.
  • Simplicity: Eliminate manual configuration for each service.

3. How to Consume Destination Fragments

Follow these steps to consume a Destination Fragment in your BTP subaccount:

Step 1: Create a Destination

  1. Navigate to SAP BTP Cockpit > Connectivity > Destinations .
  2. Define properties:
    • Name: my-fragment.
    • Type: HTTP.
    • URL: https://api.example.com.
    • Authentication: OAuth2ClientCredentials.
    • Client ID/Secret: Stored in BTP secrets.

Step 2: Create a Destination Using the Fragment

  1. you will have to perform API request to create a New Fragment as there is no option of creation via UI in BTP - Destination 

Step 3: Consume in Applications

Applications access the destination via the destination service:

// Example: Resolve a destination with an optional fragment and call its target URL.
// Requires: axios ^1.x

const axios = require('axios');

async function callViaDestination() {
  // Replace with your values
  const region = 'eu10'; // e.g., eu10, us10, etc.
  const destinationName = 'AVR'; // your destination name
  const fragmentName = 'APIKey'; // optional: the name of the destination fragment to apply
  const accessToken = process.env.DEST_CONF_ACCESS_TOKEN; // bearer token for Destination Configuration service

  const baseUrl = `https://destination-configuration.cfapps.${region}.hana.ondemand.com`;
  const destUrl = `${baseUrl}/destination-configuration/v1/destinations/${encodeURIComponent(destinationName)}`;

  try {
    // 1) Resolve destination (apply fragment via header if provided)
    const headers = {
      'Authorization': `Bearer ${accessToken}`,
      'Accept': 'application/json',
    };
    if (fragmentName) {
      headers['X-Fragment-Name'] = fragmentName; // apply fragment
    }

    const { data: destination } = await axios.get(destUrl, { headers });

    // destination typically includes properties like URL, headers, and possibly Authorization
    // depending on the auth type configured in the destination.
    const targetUrl = destination.URL;
    const targetHeaders = { ...(destination.headers || {}) };

    // If the resolved destination returns an Authorization header (e.g., OAuth flow handled by Destination service),
    // propagate it to the call below.
    if (destination.Authorization) {
      targetHeaders['Authorization'] = destination.Authorization;
    }

    // 2) Call the resolved target URL (GET as example)
    const response = await axios.get(targetUrl, {
      headers: targetHeaders,
      // If your destination requires additional headers like sap-client etc.,
      // they may be present in destination.properties or destination.headers.
      // You can map them into targetHeaders as needed.
    });

    console.log('Status:', response.status);
    console.log('Data:', response.data);
  } catch (err) {
    // Helpful diagnostics
    if (err.response) {
      console.error('Destination/Target call failed:', err.response.status, err.response.data);
    } else {
      console.error('Error:', err.message);
    }
  }
}

callViaDestination();

4. Use Cases & Diagrams

Use Case 1: SAP Build Apps (Low-Code)

Scenario: A Build App needs to fetch data from SAP S/4HANA Sales Orders.

  • Fragment: Preconfigured with OAuth2ClientCredentials and S/4HANA endpoint.
  • Consumption: Drag-and-drop the destination into the appâ€™s data source.

Diagram:

Use Case 2: SAP Process Automation

Scenario: A workflow triggers an external payment gateway API.

  • Fragment: Includes API URL, Basic Auth, and retry policies.
  • Consumption: Use the destination name in a REST API step.

Diagram:

Use Case 3: CAP-Based Applications

Scenario: A CAP service reads data from a custom API.

  • Fragment: Configured with JWT Bearer token and CORS settings.
  • Consumption: Reference the destination in cds.env.

Diagram:

5. Key Benefits

  • Accelerated Development: Reduce integration time by 40%+ using pre-configured fragments.
  • Consistent Security: Enforce MFA, encryption, and auditing across all apps.
  • Centralized Control: Update endpoints/authentications once; changes propagate everywhere.
  • Compliance: Align with ISO 27001, GDPR, and enterprise security policies.

6. Conclusion

Destination Fragments in SAP BTP are a game-changer for developers, enabling secure, reusable, and governance-ready integrations. Whether youâ€™re building low-code apps, automating processes, or developing enterprise services, fragments simplify connectivity while maintaining security and compliance.

Next Steps:

  • Explore the SAP BTP Destination Documentation.
  • Try fragments in the SAP BTP Destination Fragment API Doc.

By leveraging Destination Fragments, you future-proof your integrations and focus on innovationâ€”not configuration chaos.

entry.title: Transportation management- Import Freight charges to be paid to Goods PO supplier
entry.content:
Dear Experts,

When running the TM module for handling Import Freight charges, there are specific freight charges that need to be paid to the PO supplier.

In our case, the PO supplier of goods is different to the Freight Carrier.  Through TM process we are able to capture freight costs (payable to freight Carrier) and do the Freight cost distribution over material inventory on accruals posting. But, additionally there are a few freight costs payable to the PO supplier of Goods ONLY, these costs we need to record for only few items of the PO (in partials quantities) will be liable to these costs.  The PO contains more than 100 line items and each freight unit may contain only 10 or less number of items with partial quantities.

Thus, we can not handle these charges in the below methods:

  1. Add these freight charges in the header level PO charges. Since these are intended to be split over only the Freight unit items.
  2. Add these charges in Item level - the freight units have 10 - 15 items, ideally. The Buyer can not go into individual PO line charges and distribute the freight charges before GRN.
  3. Add these charges as unplanned delivery costs in the MIRO booking- the invoice booking takes more than 10 days from the date of GRN. In this case the stock liable to load these charges may get consumed and the product costing batch wise, may get affected.

We need your advice on how to capture these freight charges in the our P2P process with TM.

Thanks,

Zahir

entry.title: Re: Transportation Module- freight Order Purchase Organiz...
entry.content:
Good day @Rajkumar1989

Thank you for your question

The public cloud offers you the possibility to have purchasing organisation and purchasing Group filled on the Freight Order by using TM organisational unit determination, which is a standard TM logic. The values in the system acts as a selection criterion and thereby influences settlement and service purchasing. See https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_S4HANA_CLOUD/588780cab2774a7ab9fffca3a7f919fe/a5727114640e49879bbf10c6b979bd4e.html?locale=en-US & https://learning.sap.com/courses/charges-and-settlement-in-sap-s-4hana-transportation-management/mapping-freight-settlement-to-materials-management for more details.

What the public cloud does not offer you is a standard configuration that enables you to copy Purchasing Organisation and Purchasing Group from a preceding reference PO into the Freight Order as field copy rule.

Best practice:

The best approach is to use the standard TM. Which is to determine the Freight Order purchasing org in a group based on your organisational determination inputs that are available during freight oder creation. I therefore, recommend you consider implementing API for Freight Order (A2X) to enable you update the purchasing organisation and Purchasing Group. As soon as the system creates the Freight Order which is based on Freight order event, you will be able to trigger the API to update the Purchasing organisation and Purchasing Group.

 

Let me know if you have further questions.

 

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: SAP BNAC as AAS Server: Driving Interoperability and Efficiency in Digital Twin Collaboration
entry.content:
SAP Business Network Asset Collaboration  (BNAC) is taking a major leap forward in enabling standardized, interoperable digital twin ecosystems. With its latest innovation, SAP BNAC now acts as an Asset Administration Shell (AAS) Server, supporting AAS APIs and delivering seamless integration across the value chain. This capability empowers OEMs, operators, and suppliers to exchange asset data efficiently, automate processes, and prepare for compliance with initiatives like the Digital Product Passport (DPP).

Why AAS Matters

The Asset Administration Shell (IEC 63278) is the Industry 4.0 standard for representing a digital twin of an assetâ€”whether a component, machine, or plant. It structures master data, documentation, and operational data into Submodels (e.g., Digital Nameplate, Handover Documentation) and exposes them via standardized APIs. This eliminates custom integrations and ensures consistent semantics across partners.

By supporting AAS APIs, SAP BNAC becomes a native AAS Server in your digital twin landscape. This means:

  • Consume, create, and manage AAS content directly in SAP BNAC
  • Connect suppliers, OEMs, and operators using industry standards
  • Enable end-to-end collaboration without manual data translation

Whatâ€™s New: SAP BNAC as AAS Server

With AAS API support, SAP BNAC offers:

  • Standardized AAS onboarding: Suppliers upload AAS and Submodels* via APIs.
  • Automated mapping: AAS elements are translated into SAP business objects (Model, Equipment, Documents).
  • Interoperability at scale: Connect with external AAS systems and ecosystems like Factory-X.

Note (*): Supported submodels (e.g., Digital Nameplate, Handover Documentation)

Key Use Cases

1) Streamlined Onboarding of Asset Data into Business Systems (import of AAS via AAS API)

Traditionally, AAS data was imported via file-based methods (read my previous article if you want to learn more on how SAP BNAC already support AASX import). Now, SAP BNAC enables API-based AAS import, streamlining collaboration between manufacturers and system integrators.

How it works:

  • A system integrator retrieves AAS and Submodels from suppliers via APIs to SAP BNAC as AAS Server.
  • SAP BNAC automatically creates corresponding business objects:
    • Model (AAS Type)
    • Equipment (AAS Instance)
    • Documents
  • Data syncs with SAP ERP for processes like purchase orders (**).

Note (**): SAP BNAC and SAP ERP requires initial configuration (mapping BNAC objects to existing ERP classes and characteristics)

Business Value:

  • Faster onboarding of component data (e.g., motors, controllers, valves).
  • Reduced manual effort and error-prone mapping.
  • Improved collaboration during asset definition.

2) End-to-End ERPâ€“AAS Integration

Beyond import, SAP BNAC supports AAS export via AAS APIs, enabling organizations to share standardized digital twins derived from SAP ERP data.

How it works:

  • Materials and Equipment from SAP ERP are replicated in SAP BNAC.
  • Classified using Templates aligned with AAS Submodels (Digital Nameplate).
  • Exposed via AAS APIs for third-party systems.

Note: additional configuration and mapping between SAP ERP and SAP BNAC needed. Also, AAS and Submodels metadata (e.g., AAS id) must be added in SAP BNAC.

Business Value:

  • Out-of-the-box interoperability: AAS and Submodels like Digital Nameplate are derived out of ERP.
  • Enhanced transparency across the asset lifecycle.
  • Easier integration with 3rd party systems via AAS APIs.

Why This Matters for OEMs and Operators

  • Efficiency without custom integrations: Standards-based APIs reduce complexity and cost as well as make it easier to bring asset data into your business processes.
  • Rich collaboration: Access technical data, certificates, manuals, and more through AAS Submodels.
  • Future-proof: Prepare for DPP and Industry 4.0 ecosystems.

Getting Started

Explore:

  • SAP BNAC Product Documentation
  • AAS API Overview

Takeaways

SAP BNAC as AAS Server is more than a technical enhancementâ€”itâ€™s a strategic enabler for digital twin collaboration. By leveraging AAS standards, businesses can:

  • Automate asset data creation.
  • Accelerate supplier onboarding.
  • Ensure compliance and interoperability.
  • Unlock new value streams through richer networks and standardized data exchange.

What is next

What is next - our journey has just started. Our plan is support additional Submodels and ensure that you will be compliant with DPP and DPB. Got curious? Please reach out to us and be part of this journey!

entry.title: Converting Property Graphs to Knowledge Graphs in SAP HANA Cloud: A Simple Guide
entry.content:
Graphs are becoming a core part of how businesses understand their data. In SAP HANA Cloud, we already support strong property graph capabilities through the property graph engine, and a rich RDF/Knowledge Graph model through the knowledge graph engine. Until now, these two worlds lived separately.

 With our new built-in graph procedure, we make it possible to turn a property graph into a knowledge graph (RDF) in one step. This gives customers the best of both worlds: the flexibility of property graphs and the semantic richness of RDF. This blog walks through the idea in simple terms and shows how it works behind the scenes.

Before we jump into details, letâ€™s understand why we would want to convert a property graph to a knowledge graph:

Customers often start with a property graph because it is easy to model, easy to modify, and great for traversal and analytics.
Over time, they want additional capabilities like:

  • a standardized representation of entities
  • richer semantic modeling
  • SPARQL querying
  • interoperability with external tools
  • grounding their data for AI, LLMs, and RAG pipelines

Knowledge graphs shine here. By converting property graphs to the RDF format, teams can keep using their familiar structure while unlocking a wider ecosystem.

The new built-in procedure

SAP HANA Cloud introduces a simple, built-in procedure from its QRC4 2025 release: RDF_GRAPH_FROM_GRAPH_WORKSPACE. This procedure converts a property graph workspace into an RDF graph (knowledge graph).
It copies the graph data, but keeps the models independent. This means updates to one donâ€™t automatically reflect in the other.

A simple supply chain graph example

To make this more tangible, letâ€™s walk through a small but realistic example.

Imagine a supply chain graph with three main tables:

  • Suppliers - Each supplier has attributes like name, country, and risk level.
  • Materials - Materials represent the goods being supplied.
  • Shipments - Shipments connect suppliers to materials and carry business context such as shipment status and delay days.

In SAP HANA Cloud, we will first model this as a property graph workspace.

  • Suppliers and materials are vertex tables
  • Shipments are an edge table connecting suppliers to materials
  • Shipment specific attributes remain attached to the edge

This structure is very natural for operational and analytical use cases. You can easily answer questions like:

  • Which suppliers provide a given material?
  • Which suppliers are associated with delayed shipments?
  • How does risk propagate through the supply network?

Creating the property graph

At the data level, the graph is built on top of relational tables. Suppliers and materials are modeled as vertex tables, while shipments act as the edge table connecting them. Once the tables are defined, a graph workspace ties everything together:

Step 1: Letâ€™s begin with creating plain relational tables.

Suppliers

CREATE SCHEMA SCM;
SET SCHEMA SCM;
CREATE TABLE SCM.SUPPLIERS (
  SUPPLIERID NVARCHAR(50) PRIMARY KEY,
  NAME       NVARCHAR(100),
  COUNTRY    NVARCHAR(50),
  RISKLEVEL  NVARCHAR(20)
);

Materials

CREATE TABLE SCM.MATERIALS (
  MATERIALID NVARCHAR(50) PRIMARY KEY,
  NAME       NVARCHAR(100)
);

Shipments (relationship data)

CREATE TABLE SCM.SHIPMENTS (
  SHIPMENTID NVARCHAR(50) PRIMARY KEY,
  SUPPLIER   NVARCHAR(50) NOT NULL,
  MATERIAL   NVARCHAR(50) NOT NULL,
  STATUS     NVARCHAR(20),
  DELAYDAYS  INTEGER
);

Step 2: Insert sample data in the created tables

--Suppliers
INSERT INTO SCM.SUPPLIERS (SupplierID, Name, Country, RiskLevel)
VALUES ('S1', 'Alpha Metals', 'China', 'High');

INSERT INTO SCM.SUPPLIERS (SupplierID, Name, Country, RiskLevel)
VALUES ('S2', 'Nordic Steel', 'Sweden', 'Low');

INSERT INTO SCM.SUPPLIERS (SupplierID, Name, Country, RiskLevel)
VALUES ('S3', 'TerraChem', 'Brazil', 'Medium');

--Materials
INSERT INTO SCM.MATERIALS (MaterialID, Name)
VALUES ('M1', 'Steel Rods');

INSERT INTO SCM.MATERIALS (MaterialID, Name)
VALUES ('M2', 'Copper Wire');

--Shipments
INSERT INTO SCM.SHIPMENTS (ShipmentID, Supplier, Material, Status, DelayDays)
VALUES ('SH1', 'S1', 'M1', 'Delayed', 12);

INSERT INTO SCM.SHIPMENTS (ShipmentID, Supplier, Material, Status, DelayDays)
VALUES ('SH2', 'S2', 'M1', 'OnTime', 0);

INSERT INTO SCM.SHIPMENTS (ShipmentID, Supplier, Material, Status, DelayDays)
VALUES ('SH3', 'S3', 'M2', 'Delayed', 5);

At this point, the data is still relational.

Step 3: Create a property graph workspace

Now we turn the above tables into a graph workspace - SUPPLY_GRAPH.

CREATE GRAPH WORKSPACE SCM.SUPPLY_GRAPH
  VERTEX TABLE SCM.SUPPLIERS
    KEY SUPPLIERID
  VERTEX TABLE SCM.MATERIALS
    KEY MATERIALID
  EDGE TABLE SCM.SHIPMENTS
    KEY SHIPMENTID
    SOURCE SUPPLIER REFERENCES SCM.SUPPLIERS
    TARGET MATERIAL REFERENCES SCM.MATERIALS;

What this gives us:

  • Vertices
    • Suppliers with properties like name, country, risk level
    • Materials with their attributes
  • Edges
    • Shipments connecting suppliers to materials
    • Edge properties such as status and delay days

This graph is optimized for traversal and graph algorithms.

Step 4: Whatâ€™s new in QRC4 2025 - Property Graph (PG) to Knowledge Graph (KG) conversion

This is where the new functionality - RDF_GRAPH_FROM_GRAPH_WORKSPACE  comes in.  It converts an existing graph workspace into an RDF knowledge graph - 'scmkg'.

The conversion call :

CALL RDF_GRAPH_FROM_GRAPH_WORKSPACE(
    GRAPH_WORKSPACE_SCHEMA_NAME => 'SCM',
    GRAPH_WORKSPACE_NAME        => 'SUPPLY_GRAPH',
    TARGET_GRAPH_URI            => '<scmkg>',
    MAPPING_MODE                => 'AUTO',
    MAPPING_OUT                 => ?
);

Step 5: How the conversion works (in simple terms)

The conversion follows a few clear rules.

Vertices become RDF triples - Each vertex is converted into multiple RDF triples.

  • The vertex key becomes the subject
  • Each attribute becomes a predicate
  • Attribute values become objects

For example, a supplier like Alpha Metals becomes a set of triples such as:

<http://SCM/SUPPLIERS/SUPPLIERID/S1> <http://SCM/SUPPLIERS/NAME> "Alpha Metals" .
<http://SCM/SUPPLIERS/SUPPLIERID/S1> <http://SCM/SUPPLIERS/COUNTRY> "China" .
<http://SCM/SUPPLIERS/SUPPLIERID/S1> <http://SCM/SUPPLIERS/RISKLEVEL> "High" .

This directly mirrors the rows in the vertex table.

Vertex types become rdf:type - Vertex labels are converted into RDF classes.

Conceptually, this means:

<Suppliers/S1> rdf:type <Supplier> .
<Materials/M1> rdf:type <Material> .

This adds semantic meaning and allows tools and queries to reason about what kind of thing each node represents.

Step 6: Mapping modes and URI control

By default, the system generates URIs automatically. These are predictable, but often not ideal for long term semantic use. To give users full control, the conversion supports an optional mapping table, where you can define: schema, table, attribute, RDF URI, data type, optional language tags.

Using a mapping table allows customers to:

  • apply meaningful, business-friendly URIs
  • align with existing vocabularies
  • standardize naming across systems

If a mapping table is not provided, the system falls back to sensible defaults:

  • URIs are generated in the form - https://localhost/<schema>/<table>/<attribute>
  • Vertex labels default to table names
  • Unmapped attributes are handled based on the selected mapping mode

This makes it easy to get started without extra configuration.

Mapping modes that fit different customer needs

The conversion supports multiple modes, depending on how strict or exploratory the user wants to be. These modes are also described in the official documentation. 

  • AUTO (default) - Uses mapping table entries when provided, otherwise generates system URIs.
  • MAPPING_ONLY - Generates mapping output without creating RDF. Useful for validation.
  • IGNORE - Converts only attributes explicitly listed in the mapping table.
  • STRICT - Requires all attributes to be mapped. Fails if anything is missing.

 You can also supply a mapping table to assign clean, meaningful URIs and prefixes, including standard vocabularies like FOAF. An out-mapping table is generated automatically so users can inspect exactly how attributes were mapped.

Step 7: Query the knowledge graph with SPARQL

Once the RDF graph is created, it can be queried directly inside SAP HANA Cloud using SPARQL_TABLE or SPARQL_EXECUTE functions.

View the RDF graph created:

SELECT *
FROM SPARQL_TABLE('
PREFIX rdf:<http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#>
PREFIX ex:<http://example.org/scm/>

SELECT ?subject ?predicate ?obj
FROM <scmkg>
WHERE {
  ?subject ?predicate ?obj .
}
');

The below SPARQL query retrieves which suppliers ship which materials by traversing shipment relationships in the converted knowledge graph.

SELECT *
FROM SPARQL_TABLE('
SELECT DISTINCT ?supplierName ?materialName
FROM <scmkg>
WHERE {
  # ensure the embedded shipment triple exists
  FILTER EXISTS {
     << ?supplier <http://SCM/SHIPMENTS/SHIPMENTS> ?material >> ?p ?o .
  }
  # supplier attributes
  ?supplier <http://SCM/SUPPLIERS/NAME> ?supplierName .
  # material attributes
  ?material <http://SCM/MATERIALS/NAME> ?materialName .
}
');

The same data you modeled as a property graph is now available through standard SPARQL queries.

Key benefits for customers:

  1. Standardized representation - RDF makes data interoperable across tools, platforms, and organizational boundaries.
  2. Richer semantics - Customers can define precise meanings through URIs, classes, and vocabularies.
  3. Easy integration with AI - Knowledge graphs are becoming foundational for RAG systems and reasoning. This conversion gives customers a clean way to prepare their graph data for LLM based applications.
  4. No need to duplicate data models - Users start with property graphs and layer semantics later as needed.
  5. Works with existing HANA Cloud graph workspaces - Nothing special is required on the modeling side.

Looking ahead

This blog is intended as an introduction and starting point for the new Property Graph to Knowledge Graph conversion capability in SAP HANA Cloud. It represents the first step toward deeper interoperability between the property graph engine and the knowledge graph engine. The long-term vision is to reduce barriers between the two and allow users to move freely between graph patterns as their needs evolve. On our roadmap, we also plan to support conversion in the opposite direction, from knowledge graphs back to property graphs, helping to close the loop.

As graph workloads continue to grow inside SAP HANA Cloud, customers increasingly want both modeling flexibility and semantic power. With this new PG to KG conversion feature, we provide an easy entry point into the world of knowledge graphs without changing how data is modeled or stored today.

This blog focuses on introducing the core concepts and mechanics in simpler terms. In a follow-up blog, I look forward to diving deeper into a real-world use case example and exploring advanced mappings and scenarios that this capability is designed to handle.
